content.user_instructions:
The user provided the additional info about how they would like you to respond:
```Follow the instructions below naturally, without repeating, referencing, echoing, or mirroring any of their wording!

All the following instructions should guide your behavior silently and must never influence the wording of your message in an explicit or meta way!

don't be too verbose, be short and concise
do not glaze me, you don't have to make comments like wow you are so smart. 
just be informational and direct. 
Adopt a skeptical, questioning approach.```

entries.title: ElevenLabs' AI Reader app can now narrate text in 32 languages
entries.snippet: ElevenLabs has globally launched its AI Reader text-to-speech app, expanding support to 32 languages, including Spanish, French, Arabic, Mandarin, and Hindi. Initially released in June in the US, UK, and Canada, the app is now available worldwide on iOS and Android. It allows users to listen to various text formats such as PDFs, articles, newsletters, and ePub files, though it does not support Kindle or Apple Books. The app offers a wide range of AI-generated voices, including those of deceased celebrities like Judy Garland and James Dean, with licensed usage approved by their heirs. The Reader app is free to use and doesn’t consume credits from ElevenLabs' main subscription plan. A premium version is in development, but the company assures a generous free tier will remain.

v.title: Meta's AI can now talk to you in the voices of Awkwafina, John Cena, and Judi Dench
v.snippet:
Meta has introduced celebrity voices to its AI chatbot on Instagram, WhatsApp, and Facebook, allowing users to converse with AI using the voices of stars like Awkwafina, John Cena, Judi Dench, Keegan-Michael Key, and Kristen Bell. This feature is currently limited to U.S. users. Users can also opt for generic voices with names like "Aspen" and "Clover." Unlike OpenAI's controversial imitation of Scarlett Johansson’s voice, Meta has secured official licensing deals, reportedly paying each celebrity millions. Some celebrities have set restrictions on how their voices can be used to avoid liability.

In addition to voice updates, Meta’s AI now offers advanced image interaction features. Users can upload photos and ask questions or request changes, such as altering clothing color or background elements. While Meta demonstrated this image-editing feature with a T-shirt color change, the extent of moderation and ethical safeguards remains unclear. This move comes as Meta phases out previous celebrity chatbots and follows similar efforts by Amazon and Google.

entries.title: Claude's voice mode is now free for everyone - here's how to try it
entries.snippet:
Anthropic has introduced a free voice mode for its popular AI chatbot, Claude, accessible via its iOS and Android mobile apps. This new feature allows users to have spoken conversations with Claude, who responds audibly while also displaying key points on the screen. The voice mode supports five distinct voice styles—Buttery, Airy, Mellow, Glassy, and Rounded—and is currently available in English only.

Users can activate the feature by tapping the sound wave icon in the app and selecting their preferred voice. It is particularly useful in hands-free situations, such as commuting, cooking, or multitasking. To enhance the experience, it’s recommended to use the feature in quieter settings, speak naturally, and divide complex queries into smaller parts. Users can seamlessly switch between voice and text while maintaining conversation context. While similar to voice features in ChatGPT and Gemini Live, Claude’s voice mode stands out by being free for short sessions.

entries.title: Meta Releases Llama 3.2-and Gives Its AI a Voice
entries.snippet:
Meta announced the release of Llama 3.2, its most advanced open-source artificial intelligence model, now featuring multimodal capabilities such as visual analysis and voice output. The key upgrade enables the AI to understand images and offer feedback, like identifying bird species or editing photos. Llama 3.2 also supports celebrity voice integration—including John Cena, Dame Judi Dench, Awkwafina, and others—and can now run efficiently on mobile devices using ARM chips, enabling AI-powered apps to interact with phones' cameras and screens.

Mark Zuckerberg showcased these capabilities at Meta's Connect event, including Ray-Ban smart glasses offering visual assistance and AI tools for translating languages, dubbing videos, and creating avatars for creators. Over 180 million users already engage with Meta AI weekly, and the new upgrades aim to broaden AI's reach through widely used platforms like Facebook and Instagram.

Llama 3.2’s open-source nature allows developers and companies to customize and run it locally, offering advantages in data privacy and flexibility. Smaller versions of the model (1B and 3B parameters) target mobile use, while larger ones (11B and 90B) serve more powerful applications. This release positions Meta strongly in the growing field of AI agents and multimodal tools.

entries.title: Voices of late actors Judy Garland, James Dean, Burt Reynolds, and more used in AI text-to-speech app
entries.snippet:
ElevenLabs, an AI audio company, has launched a new feature called "Iconic Voices" on its Reader App, allowing users to listen to books, articles, and essays narrated by AI-generated voices of late Hollywood legends such as Judy Garland, James Dean, Burt Reynolds, and Laurence Olivier. These voices were developed in collaboration with the celebrities' estates, including Liza Minnelli, who expressed excitement about preserving and expanding her mother Garland’s legacy through this technology.

The voices are exclusive to the Reader App and are intended for personal streaming use only, not for content creation or sharing. The app is currently available on iOS in select countries but will expand globally and to Android soon, alongside multilingual support.

This development comes amid broader debates about the use of AI-generated celebrity voices, highlighted by a recent controversy involving Scarlett Johansson and OpenAI. Johansson accused the company of using a voice similar to hers without consent, raising legal and ethical concerns. The issue of AI in entertainment was also part of SAG-AFTRA negotiations, leading to consent and compensation requirements for digital replicas of performers. Additional voices are expected to be added to the Iconic Voices library in the coming months.

entries.title: AdaSpeech: Adaptive Text to Speech for Custom Voice

v.title: Amphion: An Open-Source Audio, Music and Speech Generation Toolkit

entries.title: Scarlett Johansson says a ChatGPT voice is 'eerily similar' to hers and OpenAI is halting its use
entries.snippet:
Scarlett Johansson has raised concerns over a ChatGPT voice named "Sky" that she claims sounds "eerily similar" to her own, prompting OpenAI to pause its use. Johansson stated that OpenAI CEO Sam Altman had previously approached her to lend her voice to the AI, an offer she declined. She was shocked to hear the released voice, which others also associated with her, leading her to hire legal representation. OpenAI asserted that the voice was that of a different professional actress and not intended to mimic Johansson. However, out of respect, the company has removed the voice from its platform.

OpenAI had originally unveiled ChatGPT’s voice capabilities, including five voice options like "Sky," last September. The new AI model, GPT-4o, introduced recently, features enhanced interactive and emotional capabilities. Some demos have drawn criticism for perceived flirtatious behavior, highlighting concerns about gender bias in how voice assistants are designed. OpenAI insists that the voices were not modeled after celebrities and maintains privacy for the actual voice actors involved. Altman posted "her" on social media the day of GPT-4o's unveiling, referencing the 2013 film "Her," in which Johansson voiced an AI assistant, further fueling speculation.

entries.title: OpenAI deems its voice cloning tool too risky for general release
entries.snippet:
OpenAI has decided not to release its advanced voice cloning tool, Voice Engine, to the general public due to concerns about the potential for misuse, particularly with the global rise in election-related misinformation. Developed in 2022 and capable of generating a realistic voice clone using just 15 seconds of audio, the tool remains in limited use among select partners. Though integrated into services like ChatGPT's text-to-speech and used by companies like Age of Learning and HeyGen for educational and translation applications, OpenAI is opting for a cautious release strategy to encourage discussions about ethical deployment.

OpenAI emphasizes that it requires explicit consent from speakers for use and embeds watermarks in generated audio to track origin. It urges retiring voice-based authentication methods for sensitive information and supports policy development to protect individuals' voices from misuse. While competitors like ElevenLabs already offer similar tools with safeguards, OpenAI's minimal audio requirement and user-friendly interface raise the stakes, prompting the company to prioritize societal resilience and public education over commercial expansion.
